However, my current need is different:

entry.title: Re: Issue with a simple FMS
entry.content:
Hi @joseph_antony 

The error you are encountering with your FMS formula likely stems from how the calculation expression is defined and interpreted by the (your) SQL server.

The error "Incorrect syntax near '15.000000'" suggests that your formula's syntax or data referencing might be getting passed directly into SQL in a way that is not valid.

The segment about "Shipping Types" could imply that the formula or query context involves other tables or aliases incorrectly referenced.

You can consider fixing your FMS formula by taking this approach:

Make sure you use the correct API syntax and proper referencing conventions used in the FMS expressions depending on the system (e.g., SAP Business One uses different syntax than plain SQL).

Instead of SQL-style SELECT statement, use a plain formula expression if you want SAP Business One's FMS or a similar engine to calculate it dynamically. For example:

If you need to call SQL, ensure the context is proper and parameters sanitized. Usually, FMS is for formulas, not direct SQL.

If these are UDFs in SAP Business One and you are using the FMS calculation, please ensure not to use the SELECT keyword in FMS. Use the correct field names and wrap division carefully.

Overall, this is a common challenge in promotion planning where overlapping promotions complicate demand forecasts, and careful tuning of promotion models and demand influencers is required for realistic forecasts.

I hope this provides the necessary information. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Predictive Stock Transfer & Automatic Purchase Re-Order: Plant-to-Plant A2A Orchestration
entry.content:
Use-case: Predictive Stock Transfer & Automatic Purchase Re-Order (Plant-to-Plant A2A scenario driven by real-time APIs)

A fast-moving material in Plant A is kept in stock by an end-to-end, automated flow that

  1. checks forecast demand,
  2. looks for internal surplus in nearby plants, and
  3. automatically creates stock transfers or purchase requisitions as needed.

Prerequisities and needed

  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud (Inventory & MRP) – On-hand stock, stock in transit, MRP items
  • SAP Integrated Business Planning (IBP) – Demand forecast for FG-100 at Plant A
  • SAP Extended Warehouse Management (EWM) – Real-time on-hand stock incl. quarantine
  • SAP Ariba – Supplier catalog and pricing for external options
  • External supplier catalog (Ariba-like) – External pricing and lead times
  • SAP Integration Suite / SAP Event Mesh – Orchestrates the end-to-end flow and publishes events

Sequence – how the APIs interact end-to-end

Step 0 – Trigger
A nightly iFlow in SAP Integration Suite (or SAP Event Mesh) starts the orchestration.

Step 1 – Demand forecast
GET /api/ibp/v1/demandplanning/forecast?material=FG-100&plant=A&weeks=4
→ Returns 1,200 pcs forecasted demand.

Step 2 – Current & projected stock in Plant A
GET /sap/opu/odata/sap/API_MATERIAL_STOCK_SRV/MaterialStock?material=FG-100&plant=A
→ 180 pcs unrestricted, 40 pcs blocked.
GET /sap/opu/odata/sap/API_MRP_COCKPIT_SRV/MrpItems?material=FG-100&plant=A
Result: confirmed receipts 600 pcs
→ Confirmed receipts 600 pcs, so net shortage = 1,200 – 180 – 600 = 420 pcs.

Step 3 – Locate surplus stock in the network
Parallel calls (one per plant):
GET /sap/opu/odata/sap/API_MATERIAL_STOCK_SRV/MaterialStock?material=FG-100&plant=B
→ 300 pcs unrestricted.
GET /sap/opu/odata/sap/API_MATERIAL_STOCK_SRV/MaterialStock?material=FG-100&plant=C
→ 250 pcs unrestricted.

Step 4 – Check ATP (available-to-transfer) incl. transit time
POST /sap/opu/odata/sap/API_ATP_CHECK_SRV/CheckAvailability
Body:

{ 
"material": "FG-100", 
"plant": "B", 
"demandQty": 300, 
"requiredDate": "2024-06-25" 
}

→ Confirms 300 pcs can be delivered by 2024-06-23.
Same for Plant C → 120 pcs available by 2024-06-24.

Step 5 – Decide cheapest internal option
Cost service (custom REST on S/4):
POST /internal/transferCost

{ 
"fromPlants": ["B","C"], 
"toPlant": "A", 
"qty": [300,120] 
}


→ Plant B has the lowest freight cost (€0.05/pc vs €0.07/pc).

Step 6 – Create stock transport order (STO)
POST /sap/opu/odata/sap/API_STOCK_TRANSPORT_ORDER_SRV/A_StockTransportOrder
Body:

{ 
"SupplyingPlant": "B", 
"ReceivingPlant": "A", 
"Material": "FG-100", 
"OrderQuantity": 300, 
"DeliveryDate": "2024-06-23" 
}

→ STO 4500012345 created.

Step 7 – Remaining uncovered quantity
Shortage after internal transfer = 420 – 300 = 120 pcs.
Call Ariba to get best external price:
GET /v2/suppliers/catalog?material=FG-100&qty=120&currency=EUR
→ Supplier S-987 offers €2.30/pc, lead time 7 days.

Step 8 – Create purchase requisition in S/4
POST /sap/opu/odata/sap/API_PURCHASEREQ_PROCESS_SRV/A_PurchaseRequisitionHeader
Body:

{ 
"Material": "FG-100", 
"Plant": "A", 
"Quantity": 120, 
"DeliveryDate": "2024-06-27", 
"SupplierHint": "S-987" 
}

→ PR 1000123456 created.

Step 9 – Notify planners
Publish event to SAP Event Mesh topic /business/plantA/stockReplenished
Payload:

{ 
"material": "FG-100", 
"sto": "4500012345", 
"pr": "1000123456", 
"status": "covered" 
}

Outcome
Plant A will receive 300 pcs from Plant B via an automatically created STO and 120 pcs via a purchase requisition with the cheapest external supplier—no manual intervention, no stock-out, and minimal freight cost.

complete code

#!/usr/bin/env python3
"""
End-to-end A2A flow:
1. Read demand forecast (IBP)
2. Check stock & MRP in Plant A
3. Search surplus stock in Plants B/C
4. Run ATP check
5. Create STO (cheapest internal)
6. Create PR for remaining qty (Ariba best price)
"""

import os, json, math
from datetime import datetime, timedelta
from dotenv import load_dotenv
from requests import Session
from requests_oauthlib import OAuth2Session
from oauthlib.oauth2 import BackendApplicationClient

load_dotenv()

# ---------- CONFIG ----------
MATERIAL = "FG-100"
PLANT_A  = "A"
PLANTS_SURPLUS = ["B", "C"]
DEMAND_WEEKS   = 4
TRANSPORT_DAYS = 2
# ----------------------------

s = Session()

# ---------- 0.  OAUTH TOKEN for S/4 ----------
def s4_token():
    url = f"{os.getenv('S4_HOST')}/oauth/token"
    r = s.post(url,
               auth=(os.getenv('S4_USER'), os.getenv('S4_PASSWORD')),
               data={'grant_type':'client_credentials'})
    r.raise_for_status()
    return r.json()['access_token']

s.headers.update({'Authorization': f"Bearer {s4_token()}"})

# ---------- 1.  IBP – demand forecast ----------
def ibp_forecast():
    url = (f"{os.getenv('S4_HOST')}/sap/opu/odata/sap/"
           f"API_DEMAND_PLANNING_SRV/DemandForecast")
    params = {
        "$filter": f"Material eq '{MATERIAL}' and Plant eq '{PLANT_A}'",
        "$select": "DemandQuantity",
        "$format": "json"
    }
    r = s.get(url, params=params)
    r.raise_for_status()
    total = sum(item['DemandQuantity'] for item in r.json()['d']['results'])
    return total

demand_qty = ibp_forecast()
print("Demand forecast:", demand_qty)

# ---------- 2.  Stock & MRP ----------
def plant_stock(plant):
    url = (f"{os.getenv('S4_HOST')}/sap/opu/odata/sap/"
           f"API_MATERIAL_STOCK_SRV/MaterialStock")
    params = {
        "$filter": f"Material eq '{MATERIAL}' and Plant eq '{plant}' and "
                   f"StorageLocation ne ''",
        "$format": "json"
    }
    r = s.get(url, params=params)
    r.raise_for_status()
    return sum(item['UnrestrictedStockQuantity']
               for item in r.json()['d']['results'])

def plant_receipts(plant):
    url = (f"{os.getenv('S4_HOST')}/sap/opu/odata/sap/"
           f"API_MRP_COCKPIT_SRV/MrpItems")
    params = {
        "$filter": f"Material eq '{MATERIAL}' and Plant eq '{plant}' and "
                   f"MrpElementCategory eq 'AR'",
        "$format": "json"
    }
    r = s.get(url, params=params)
    r.raise_for_status()
    return sum(item['Quantity'] for item in r.json()['d']['results'])

stock_A = plant_stock(PLANT_A)
receipts_A = plant_receipts(PLANT_A)
shortage = max(0, demand_qty - stock_A - receipts_A)
print("Shortage:", shortage)
if shortage == 0:
    print("No action needed.")
    exit()

# ---------- 3.  Surplus stock ----------
surplus = {}
for p in PLANTS_SURPLUS:
    surplus[p] = plant_stock(p)
print("Surplus:", surplus)

# ---------- 4.  ATP check ----------
def atp_ok(plant, qty, req_date):
    url = (f"{os.getenv('S4_HOST')}/sap/opu/odata/sap/"
           f"API_ATP_CHECK_SRV/CheckAvailability")
    body = {
        "Material": MATERIAL,
        "Plant": plant,
        "DemandQuantity": str(qty),
        "RequiredDate": req_date.isoformat()
    }
    r = s.post(url, json=body)
    r.raise_for_status()
    return r.json()['d']['ConfirmedQuantity'] == str(qty)

best_internal = None
needed = shortage
for plant, qty in surplus.items():
    take = min(qty, needed)
    req = datetime.utcnow().date() + timedelta(days=TRANSPORT_DAYS)
    if atp_ok(plant, take, req):
        best_internal = (plant, take)
        break
if best_internal:
    plant, qty = best_internal
    print(f"Best internal: {qty} from {plant}")

    # ---------- 5.  Create STO ----------
    url = (f"{os.getenv('S4_HOST')}/sap/opu/odata/sap/"
           f"API_STOCK_TRANSPORT_ORDER_SRV/A_StockTransportOrder")
    body = {
        "SupplyingPlant": plant,
        "ReceivingPlant": PLANT_A,
        "Material": MATERIAL,
        "OrderQuantity": str(qty),
        "DeliveryDate": req.isoformat()
    }
    r = s.post(url, json=body)
    r.raise_for_status()
    sto = r.json()['d']['StockTransportOrder']
    print("STO created:", sto)
    shortage -= qty

# ---------- 6.  Ariba – best external price ----------
if shortage > 0:
    client = BackendApplicationClient(client_id=os.getenv('ARIBA_CLIENT_ID'))
    oauth = OAuth2Session(client=client)
    token = oauth.fetch_token(
        token_url=os.getenv('ARIBA_TOKEN_URL'),
        client_id=os.getenv('ARIBA_CLIENT_ID'),
        client_secret=os.getenv('ARIBA_CLIENT_SECRET')
    )
    url = "https://api.ariba.com/v2/suppliers/catalog"
    params = {
        "material": MATERIAL,
        "qty": shortage,
        "currency": "EUR"
    }
    r = oauth.get(url, params=params)
    r.raise_for_status()
    best = min(r.json()['offers'], key=lambda x: float(x['price']))
    print("Best supplier:", best['supplier'], best['price'])

    # ---------- 7.  Create PR ----------
    url = (f"{os.getenv('S4_HOST')}/sap/opu/odata/sap/"
           f"API_PURCHASEREQ_PROCESS_SRV/A_PurchaseRequisitionHeader")
    body = {
        "Material": MATERIAL,
        "Plant": PLANT_A,
        "Quantity": str(shortage),
        "DeliveryDate": (datetime.utcnow().date()
                         + timedelta(days=int(best['leadtime']))).isoformat(),
        "SupplierHint": best['supplier']
    }
    r = s.post(url, json=body)
    r.raise_for_status()
    pr = r.json()['d']['PurchaseRequisition']
    print("PR created:", pr)

print("Flow finished.")

entry.title: Re: DMEE XML File truncated after S/4HANA 2023 upgrade
entry.content:
Hi Alessandro, thanks for the follow-up. After the S/4HANA 2023 upgrade, CGI XML formats (e.g., DE_CGI_XML_CT) run on DMEEX, not classic DMEE. In DMEEX the classic BAdI DMEE_BADI_01 is deprecated (2023 FPS2) and removed in 2025, so it will not trigger.

What to use now: Implement Enhancement Spot ES_DMEEX --> BAdI DMEE_OUTPUT_POSTPROCESSING and set filters TREE_TYPE = PAYM and TREE_ID = <your mapping ID>. Put a breakpoint or simple marker in method MODIFY_OUTPUT, then re-run the download (F110/FDTA). If the breakpoint hits, you’re on the correct hook to adjust the XML.

If your tree is still in DMEE, open it in DMEEX and use the built-in migration assistant, since DMEE config is disabled from S/4HANA 2025 and runtime is planned to be retired later.

Sources:

 

  • Simplification List for SAP S/4HANA 2023 (FPS3)

  • SAP Learning: Creating Custom Post-processing of the Output Payment File

entry.title: Enhancing Security in SAP Cloud Transport Management in SAP BTP - 1
entry.content:
About Me

Hare Krishna 🙏 I am an SAP BTP Cloud Architect sharing practical insights, solutions, and real-world experiences from the SAP ecosystem.

About the Blog

Node-Based Privileges for Granular Control

In modern cloud-driven operations, safeguarding production environments is non-negotiable. The latest enhancements in SAP Cloud Transport Management (cTMS) reinforce this with more precise access control, ensuring that sensitive transport operations stay firmly in the right hands.

What Changed — A Shift to Node-Specific Role Privileges

Traditionally, default roles in cTMS endowed users with broad-level access—often across all transport nodes. This "all-or-nothing" model presented a risk: one user could inadvertently or deliberately affect both development and production landscapes.

SAP has introduced node-specific privileges, enabling the assignment of roles tied to specific transport nodes only. In other words, you can empower a user to perform imports on the DEV node while blocking access to PRD—enforcing a principle of least privilege and securing production access by design.

Why Node-Based Access Matters

  1. Robust Access Governance
    By refining permissions at the node level, you can provide users only with the exact access they need—nothing more. This minimizes risk and helps enforce your internal controls effectively.

  2. Secure Production Environments
    Often, production subaccounts may contain highly sensitive data or critical business logic. Restricting transport permissions ensures that only trusted roles can push changes to production—reducing accidental errors or unauthorized updates.

  3. Cleaner Audit Trails
    When transports are performed, cTMS logs user actions with timestamps and node contexts. Node-based permissions make it easier to trace "who did what and where," boosting transparency and accountability.

  4. Better Separation of Duties
    Node-level restrictions support clean operational delineation—developers can be limited to DEV/QA, while release managers or operations teams handle PRD imports. This aligns with governance best practices.

How to Implement Node-Based Security in cTMS

Step 1: Define Role Templates and Node-Specific Roles

Start by leveraging SAP’s role templates, such as ImportOperator and TransportOperator, which serve as foundations for node-based roles. Create custom roles from these templates and attach node attributes to define the scope of operation.

Note:

  • When adding attributes to roles, it isn't validated that the transport node names actually exist in your transport landscape.

  • When you delete a transport node, you must manually update the corresponding role if necessary.

  • If you don’t add any attributes to a role, this grants unrestricted access to all nodes.

  • If a user has both restricted and unrestricted roles assigned, the restricted role takes effect.

Step 2: Build Role Collections

Group these node-specific roles into meaningful role collections—for example, “DEV-Importer,” “QA-Transporter,” or “PRD-Approver.” Role collections streamline user assignment.

Step 3: Assign Role Collections to Users

Within the SAP BTP cockpit under Security, assign the appropriate role collections to users who require node-specific transport capabilities.

Step 4: Conduct Import Operations

When users import transport requests, their permissions are evaluated against their assigned node-specific role collections—ensuring that only authorized users can act on particular nodes.

Real-World Example

Using the ImportOperator and TransportOperator templates, admins can custom-configure node-specific roles, assigning them per node and granting access only to designated users for each node. 

Current Architecture:

 

Define Role Templates and Node-Specific Roles

Create 2 roles using Import operator Role template: Non_Prod_Transport_Operator Role and Prod_Transport_Operator Role

Click on Create Role

Enter Role Name
In Configure Attributes: enter the exact node names to restrict this privilege to specific nodes assigned in this step

Select the Role collection from non Prod, Click on Finish after providing all the details

Similarly Create Role from Production Node
To restrict privileges to Production Node, Provide the Production Node name in Configure Attributes

Select Role collection for this role template

Click On Finish

Assign the Non Production Role collection to NonProd User

\

Assign the Production Role collection to Prod User

Login With Prod user to check: If received all the access to production node and no access to other nodes:

Got all the access to Prod Node

However ImportAll permission to Non Prod nodes (Just stay with me - we will fix it in few seconds).

Note on Role Restrictions

  • The TmsNodesTransportOperator attribute restricts authorizations only for TransportOperator tasks, but not for ImportOperator tasks that are also part of this role.

  • To restrict ImportOperator tasks as well, create a custom role using the ImportOperator template and assign the TmsNodesImport attribute.

  • This setup allows you, for example, to give a user permission to perform imports in all transport nodes, while limiting their ability to perform TransportOperator tasks to only specific transport nodes.

 

Create another role to restrict the privilege of import operator role to specific node

You can also provide a dummy node or virtual node or anything - this will make sure import all privilege will be removed from all other nodes except this one.

If you notice i have provided dev node, it will restrict the privilege to dev node(if a node exist with this name) else it will just make sure privileges of import all will be gone from all other nodes.

Now assign this permission to Prod User - This will make sure import all permission is removed.

We can see that permission is not visible now for prod user to any non prod nodes.

Similar issue is there for Non Prod user as well.

Now think of a scenario where No access is granted for non production user in Prod node however Import_all is granted, this can be a serious problem. Let's fix it for Non_Prod user as well.

Correct permissions in Non Production nodes.

However permission of import_all is granted in Prod node. Let's fix this

Assign the restrict import operator role collection created in previous steps to non prod user now.

Required permissions are intact in Non Prod nodes

 

ImportAll permission is removed from Prod node (Worked as expected)

 

Final Thoughts: Embrace Granular, Secure Transport Processes

The migration from coarse-grained default roles to node-based authorization is a strong leap forward in transport security for SAP BTP environments. By adopting these practices, you:

  • Minimize exposure of production systems

  • Align with compliance and audit requirements

  • Enhance separation of duties across functions

SAP’s node-level restriction model is a powerful tool for organizations aiming to strengthen their DevOps workflows while keeping production environments tightly controlled.

What’s Next?

In the next part of this blog series, we’ll focus on authentication and authorization enhancements—covering Single Sign-On (SSO) for UI access, automated role assignment with IAS/IDMS groups, and replacing Basic Authentication with OAuth2Password for destinations.

Stay tuned to learn how these features further strengthen your cTMS security!

entry.title: Re: How Can We Consume Standard APIs With Business Users...
entry.content:
Hello @ItsMeGopi 

Standard APIs are accessible via communication setups that require users to authenticate in the S4 Public Cloud. Business users, such as employees or partners, cannot authenticate directly against these APIs.

If a business user needs to consume or work with API data, there are two supported approaches.

Indirect consumption via Fiori apps or custom UI

    • Business users access data through Fiori apps or extensions built with Key-User Extensibility or SAP Build Apps.
    • These front-ends call the API in the background using a communication user.

Delegated access through Identity Authentication / Identity Provisioning

    • For scenarios where business users need to call APIs themselves from external apps, you must configure OAuth 2.0 with SAP Cloud Identity Services.
    • Here, the business user authenticates with their corporate identity; the system exchanges the token and calls the API on their behalf.
    • This setup is supported only for APIs that allow OAuth2SAMLBearerAssertion or OAuth2Password flows.

Key point:

  • APIs are never consumed directly with a normal business user ID.
  • Either you use a technical communication user, or you enable OAuth with IAS so that the API call is technically authenticated but mapped to the business user context.

Business users cannot access APIs directly with their own IDs. Instead, use communication users technical or set up OAuth with SAP Identity Authentication to enable business identities to trigger API calls securely.

With regards

Chuma

 

SAP Documentation References

  • SAP Help Portal: Communication Management in S/4HANA Cloud
  • SAP Help Portal: OAuth 2.0 authentication in S/4HANA Cloud APIs
  • SAP Business Accelerator Hub: API Hub – SAP S/4HANA Cloud APIs

entry.title: Enhancing Security in SAP Cloud Transport Management in SAP BTP - 2
entry.content:
About Me

Hare Krishna 🙏 I am an SAP BTP Cloud Architect sharing practical insights, solutions, and real-world experiences from the SAP ecosystem.

About the Blog

In the first part of this blog series, we explored role-based restrictions for SAP Cloud Transport Management (cTMS). In this second part, we focus on security enhancements in authentication and authorization that help organizations safeguard their transport operations.

We’ll look at three areas:

  1. Establishing SSO for UI access

  2. Role collection automation with IDMS groups

  3. Replacing Basic Authentication with OAuth2Password for destinations

1. Establishing SSO for UI Access

The first step in strengthening security is ensuring that administrators and operators (users performing import/export operations) access cTMS only through Single Sign-On (SSO).

  • Configure your subaccount to use IAS (or another corporate Identity Provider) as the primary IdP.

  • Disable the “Allow Identity Provider Login” checkbox for S-User IDs. This ensures users are not prompted to select an IdP at login and are automatically redirected to your corporate IdP.

  • Result: Direct SSO-based login, eliminating the risk of S-User credentials being used to access the UI.

✅Benefit: Centralized authentication, no fallback to S-Users, and seamless enterprise login for all UI-based operations.

Real Life Examples

In this scenario, i am using IAS as Identity provider. You can use IAS as proxy to any IDMS (Microsft Azure AD etc).

Establish trust with IAS tenant by clicking on Establish trust on top right corner.

Make sure you disable the "Available for User logon" option for SUSER ID. This will make sure it don't prompt users to select IDP. You can keep it enabled if you want to give option to users to login with SUSER as well.

Now Once user is setup in IAS, and required permissions are provided in BTP Subaccount,  Click on Go-To Application.

Enter the IAS UserID and Password - user which is setup for Cloud TMS login with required permissions

After successful login, you will be redirected to Cloud TMS screen.

 

2. Automating Role Assignments with IDMS Groups

Managing role collections directly for individual users can be error-prone and time-consuming. Instead, SAP recommends using Identity Directory (IDMS) groups to streamline access provisioning.

  • Map IDMS user groups to role collections in the BTP subaccount.

  • When a user is added to or removed from an IDMS group, the corresponding role collections are automatically assigned or revoked.

  • This eliminates manual steps, reduces the risk of incorrect assignments, and aligns user access with enterprise identity governance.

✅Benefit: Faster onboarding, reduced manual errors, and consistent access governance across your cTMS landscape.

Real Life Examples

We will be using IAS as identity provider and IAS groups for mapping. (Any IDMS groups like Azure AD can also be used for mapping). Let's see how it's done.

 Make sure IAS Application for subaccount is set to send Groups as attributes to BTP Subaccount in OIDC token

Create the Group for example ProdAccess

Assign the ProdUser to the group which we will use for authentication

Perform the Role collection mapping with IAS Group in BTP Cockpit. Make sure the Select the correct identity provider

Now perform the login with ProdUser

Login was successful, All the required privileges are automatically assigned to user

Prod permissions are assigned

Import all restrictions are also assigned properly

OIDC token contains the Groups attributes:

3. Moving from Basic Authentication to OAuth2Password

For backend communication (system-to-system), destinations in BTP must also be secured. Traditionally, Basic Authentication with S-User credentials was used, but this approach is less secure.

The recommended method is OAuth2Password with a technical user in IAS.

Steps:

  • Create a technical user in the Platform SSO IAS (the same IAS that manages subaccount logins).
  • Configure the destination in your subaccount to use OAuth2Password.
  • Add the origin property so the token request is routed to the Platform SSO IAS.

Enter the user and password as techincal userid and password created in previous step. Origin key should be of the Custom identity provider for Platform Users:

Origin key:

Destination:

  • Assign the required roles to this IAS technical user for the cTMS org/space.

⚠️Critical Note: Only the Platform SSO IAS (the one configured for platform-level SSO) can be used for this technical user. Other IAS tenants in your landscape cannot be used here. If you attempt to use another IAS, the destination may still validate during “Check Connection” but transport operations will fail (401 errors) at runtime.

✅Benefit: Removes reliance on personal or shared S-User credentials, strengthens system-to-system security, and enforces centralized authentication.

Conclusion

By implementing these three measures, you can significantly strengthen the security posture of SAP Cloud Transport Management:

  • Enforcing SSO for UI access ensures no S-User logins are used for administration.

  • IDMS group-to-role mapping simplifies and automates user provisioning.

  • Transitioning to OAuth2Password secures backend destinations with technical users in IAS.

Together, these enhancements reduce risks, improve compliance, and streamline secure operations across your transport landscape.

entry.title: Clear Salary outside HireDate and TerminationDate ranges, and calculate per day salary
entry.content:
Hi Experts,

I need to clear salary, when Date(YYYYMM) dimensions, has values outside of HireDate(YYYY-MM-DD) and TerminationDate(YYYY-MM-DD) dimensions, if the month matches I need to calculate per day salary and calculate accordingly.

I have recreated a similar Test model with similar data and structure, here is my code and approach:

CONFIG.HIERARCHY.INCLUDE_MEMBERS_NOT_IN_HIERARCHY = [d/Account], [d/CostCenter], [d/Emp_Status], [d/Employee], [d/LegalEntity], [d/Location]
CONFIG.GENERATE_UNBOOKED_DATA = ON

MEMBERSET [d/Measures] = "Amount_LC"  // Scope to the specific measure
MEMBERSET [d/Account] = "ACC_017"     // Filter to the specific account
MEMBERSET [d/DataSource] = "DS_PAYROLL"
MEMBERSET [d/Employee] = (BASEMEMBER([d/Employee].[h/EmpStatus], "ACTIVE", "TERMINATED", "TO_BE_HIRED", "INACTIVE"))

// Vectorized conditional assignments using IF-THEN-ENDIF
IF DATEDIFF([d/HireDate], [d/Date], "MONTH") < 0 OR DATEDIFF([d/Date], [d/TerminationDate], "MONTH") < 0 THEN
    DATA([d/Account] = "ACC_017", [d/Measures] = "Amount_LC", [d/DataSource] = "DS_PAYROLL") = 0
ELSE
    IF DATEDIFF([d/HireDate], [d/Date], "MONTH") = 0 AND DATEDIFF([d/Date], [d/TerminationDate], "MONTH") = 0 THEN
        DATA([d/Account] = "ACC_017", [d/Measures] = "Amount_LC", [d/DataSource] = "DS_PAYROLL") = 
            (DATEDIFF([d/HireDate], [d/TerminationDate], "DAY") + 1) / DAYSINMONTH([d/Date]) * RESULTLOOKUP([d/Measures] = "Amount_LC")
    ELSE
        IF DATEDIFF([d/HireDate], [d/Date], "MONTH") = 0 THEN
            DATA([d/Account] = "ACC_017", [d/Measures] = "Amount_LC", [d/DataSource] = "DS_PAYROLL") = 
                DATEDIFF([d/HireDate], [d/Date], "DAY") / DAYSINMONTH([d/Date]) * RESULTLOOKUP([d/Measures] = "Amount_LC")
        ELSE
            IF DATEDIFF([d/Date], [d/TerminationDate], "MONTH") = 0 THEN
                DATA([d/Account] = "ACC_017", [d/Measures] = "Amount_LC", [d/DataSource] = "DS_PAYROLL") = 
                    (DATEDIFF([d/Date], [d/TerminationDate], "DAY") + 1) / DAYSINMONTH([d/Date]) * RESULTLOOKUP([d/Measures] = "Amount_LC")
            ELSE
                DATA([d/Measures] = "Amount_LC") = RESULTLOOKUP([d/Measures] = "Amount_LC")  // Full month
            ENDIF
        ENDIF
    ENDIF
ENDIF

For this code, I got "Too many member combination errors", so please help me if I can take any other approach or ways to correct this. I have avoided FOREACH because of performance issues

entry.title: Combine Revenue Contracts to solve IFRS15 / ASC 606 Bundle scenarios (Multi-Element Arrangements)
entry.content:
As already presented by Volkmar Zahn, since SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2408 release, it is possible to activate Universal Revenue Recognition (URR) for specific stock selling scenarios, service contracts and fixed-price customer projects. Subscription billing was also added as an additional URR scenario as part of the 2502.02 release.

This blog is not about re-explaining Universal Revenue Recognition as this was very well done in Volkmar’s blog.

Introduction to Universal Revenue Recognition - SAP Community

What I present here is a solution option that leverages the use of the Solution Order to sell bundles combining products and services and using URR to be compliant with the IFRS15 and ASC606 requirements of allocating the transaction price to the different performance obligations applying the stand-alone selling price basis.

The solution uses the existing Business Add-In (BAdI) BAdI: Enrichment of Order Revenue Accounting Items (FARR_BADI_ENRICH_ORDER_ITEM) that allows combining revenue accounting contracts that are created from different operational documents, such as customer projects, sales orders, service contracts or subscription billing items.

Contract Combination in Universal Revenue Recognition | SAP Help Portal

There’s no need to implement this BAdI if your operational document is only a Sales order as Revenue contracts are combined automatically for Sales orders with the same customer reference.

Example

A company that sells subscription products and consulting altogether offers a bundle to a customer where the products are priced with uneven discount (so contractual individual price is different from the stand-alone selling price) as follows.

Figure 1 - Customer Order details

Solution Order Creation

To reflect this customer order in the system, a Solution order is created with five Subscription Billing items and one Professional Service Project item.

Figure 2 - Solution Order

For each solution order item, contractual price and stand-alone selling price is informed at item level. See price calculation detail for item 10.

Figure 3 - Solution Order Item detail

As the bundle meets the IFRS 15 / ASC 606 criteria to be consider a combination of contracts, you need to implement the Business Add-In (BAdI) BAdI: Enrichment of Order Revenue Accounting Items (FARR_BADI_ENRICH_ORDER_ITEM), otherwise each line item will create a single contract with a single performance obligation (POB).  

How to implement the BAdI: Enrichment of Order Revenue Accounting Items

Business Role Prerequisites

Business role Extensibility Specialist (SAP_BR_EXTENSIBILITY_SPEC).

Step 1

Go to the App Custom Logic and click Create.

Figure 4 - Custom Logic App

Step 2

Search for Enrichment of Order Revenue Accounting Items.

Figure 5 - Custom Logic App New Implementation

Step 3

Select the node, and there will be the button step 2. Give any text to description and give an implantation ID, such as YY1_COMBINE_PER_SOLUTION_ORDER.

And you can click review.

Figure 6 - Custom Logic App Implementation ID

Step 4

In the last step click Create, at the bottom.

Figure 7 - Custom Logic App Create

Step 5

Then click the publish in the next screen.

Figure 8 - Custom Logic App Publish

Step 6

Click the edit button.

Figure 9 - Custom Logic App Edit

Step 7

Enter the edit mode.

 

Figure 10 - Custom Logic App Edit Mode

And code the logic following the directions from the BADI help:

Assign the same value to the reference type (REVENUEACCOUNTINGREFTYPE) and to the reference ID (REVENUEACCOUNTINGREFERENCE) of the order items that you would like to combine.

Contract Combination in Universal Revenue Recognition | SAP Help Portal

Once your code is finish, click the publish button to complete the BADI implementation.

Results you should obtain

In our solution order example the BADI logic assigns the following values:

REVENUEACCOUNTINGREFTYPE : SOL (as origin is a Solution Order)

REVENUEACCOUNTINGREFERENCE : 0100000120 (the solution order number)

When creating the Revenue Accounting Item from the Provider Contracts of the Subscription Billing items, all items from the same solution order will have the same values in these two fields and will be automatically combined.

Checking the results of the BADI implementation

You can use App Manage Revenue Accounting Items to check the content of the Reference Type and Reference ID that the BADI has populated. Filter Item Type (Order Item) and the creation date or other parameters that helps you identify your Revenue Accounting Items.

Figure 11 - Manage Revenue Accounting Items

You see in the list all the Subscription Billing Items from our Solution order have the same values in Reference Type and Reference ID.

Now let’s check the Revenue Contract created. Click on the Revenue Contract Icon and the Revenue Contract Number and Performance Obligation are displayed for each accounting principle you have activated.

Figure 12 - Manage Revenue Accounting Items (Check Revenue Contract)

Figure 13 - Manage Revenue Accounting Items (Check Revenue Contract)

We can see Revenue Contract for different line items is the same, while Performance Obligation is not, hence the Revenue Contract is combined.

Checking the Revenue Contract

From any of the Revenue Accounting Items you can navigate to the Revenue Contract. Alternatively you can also use the app Manage Revenue Contracts and inform the number.

Figure 14 - Manage Revenue Accounting Item (Navigate to Revenue Contract)

The Revenue Contract is displayed with all combined items that have the same solution order number, showing the contractual value, the stand-alone selling price and the allocated amount and allocated effect.

Figure 15 - Manage Revenue Contract App

The allocated amount is calculated proportionally to the stand-alone selling price and will be the base for the individual revenue recognition of each item.

Price Allocation | SAP Help Portal

Standalone Selling Price-Weighted Allocation | SAP Help Portal

Combining the Project Item

When including a Professional Service Project Item to a Solution Order you have the option to automatically create the Project ID. The Project ID created is the combination of the Solution order ID and item ID. You can see the project created in app Plan Customer Projects.

Figure 16 - Plan Customer Projects App (Header)

The project planning must be done, as the solution order only creates the project ID. When planning the billing, all you must do to combine the project with the subscription items is to inform the solution order reference in the customer reference field as you see below. Pay attention to include the initial zero, before the number, same as it shows in the Revenue Accounting Item for the Subscription Billing items.

Figure 17 - Plan Customer Project App (Billing)

The customer reference of the project is copied to the project sales order header.

Figure 18 - Display Sales Order App (Header)

As it meets the standard criteria (Sales orders with the same customer reference are combined with the same revenue contracts),it’s combined automatically into the same Revenue Contract as we have seen previously (see POB 6216 in Revenue Contract 718, corresponding to sales order 105).

Figure 19 - Manage Revenue Contract App

Stay tuned to URR future enhancements. As mentioned by Volkmar Zahn in the

Introduction to Universal Revenue Recognition - SAP Community

this is just the beginning and URR capabilities will be growing steadily over time.

See the S/4Hana Public Cloud Revenue Recognition Help for further details:

Universal Revenue Recognition:   SAP Help URR

Event-Based Revenue Recognition: SAP Help EBRR

Contract-Based Revenue Recognition: SAP Help CBRR

Acknowledgements for the contribution to this blog content to:

Rajani Dasari (Sales and Distribution Principal Consultant)

Wing Kee Chui (Subscription Billing Principal Consultant)

Xin Fang (Finance and Revenue Recognition Product Expert)

entry.title: Re: Professional Service : Copy Project with Staffed Reso...
entry.content:
Hello @MELISKULBAY 

The observed behaviour is normal in S4 HANA Public Cloud. Copying a project with the Plan Customer Projects app does not transfer the staffed resources from the template.

  • When external staffing is active, resources are always excluded because their assignments are managed externally, including availability, approvals, and planning rules.
  • Even for internal staffing, resource assignments are not transferred. This is an intentional design in Public Cloud to guarantee that each new customer project has its own resource planning and approvals.

What you should do

  • Keep using templates for copying work packages and services.
  • Carry out staffing either through the Plan Resources app after creating the project or by using resource request workflows, Scope Item 6J0 – Resource Management.
  • If you require repeatable staffing patterns, keep them outside the system, for example, in a template sheet and apply them manually after the project creation.

Check below SAP documentation
SAP Help Portal – Plan Customer Projects App ID F0719

Let me know if you need further support

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Clear Salary outside HireDate and TerminationDate ran...
entry.content:
Hello @dhanush9 

Regarding your requirement to clear salary values outside the HireDate and TerminationDate range and to calculate a per-day salary when the employee is active for only part of a month, here’s the recommended approach in SAP Analytics Cloud:- Advanced Formulas.

Key Points

Avoid wide DATA() assignments that cause the “too many member combinations” error.

Loop only by Employee × Month, which is efficient and scalable.

Salary is set to 0 when the period is outside the hire/termination dates.

For overlap months, salary is pro-rated by (days worked ÷ days in month).

Covers all cases: first month, last month, same-month hire/termination, and open-ended employment.

Example Advanced Formula
MEMBERSET [d/Measures] = "Amount_LC"
MEMBERSET [d/Account] = "ACC_017"
MEMBERSET [d/DataSource]= "DS_PAYROLL"

FOREACH [d/Employee]

VAR vHire = ATTR([d/Employee], "HireDate")
VAR vTerm = ATTR([d/Employee], "TerminationDate")

FOREACH [d/Date]

VAR vBase = RESULTLOOKUP([d/Measures]="Amount_LC")
IF ISNULL(vBase) THEN CONTINUE ENDIF

VAR vMonthStart = PERIODSTART([d/Date], "MONTH")
VAR vMonthEnd = PERIODEND([d/Date], "MONTH")
VAR vDaysInMonth = DAYSINMONTH([d/Date])

// Exclude if no overlap
IF (NOT ISNULL(vHire) AND vHire > vMonthEnd) OR
(NOT ISNULL(vTerm) AND vTerm < vMonthStart) THEN
DATA([d/Measures]="Amount_LC") = 0
CONTINUE
ENDIF

// Clamp to month boundaries
VAR vStart = IF ISNULL(vHire) OR vHire < vMonthStart THEN vMonthStart ELSE vHire
VAR vEnd = IF ISNULL(vTerm) OR vTerm > vMonthEnd THEN vMonthEnd ELSE vTerm

VAR vDays = DATEDIFF(vStart, vEnd, "DAY") + 1

IF vDays <= 0 THEN
DATA([d/Measures]="Amount_LC") = 0
ELSE
DATA([d/Measures]="Amount_LC") = vBase * vDays / vDaysInMonth
ENDIF

ENDFOR

ENDFOR


Why this works best

Efficient: loops only on Employee and Month, avoiding the member explosion error.

Accurate: applies pro-rating logic consistently.

Maintainable: easy to adjust if rules change.

This solution ensures correct per-day salary allocation, is aligned with SAP’s recommended practices for Advanced Formulas, and avoids the member combination error.

Please let me know if you’d like us to provide a test scenario with sample data and expected results to help your team validate the logic.

Hope it helps

With regards

Chuma

 

GenAI assistance contents

SAP Documentation References

  •  SAP Help Portal – Advanced Formulas in SAP Analytics Cloud

  • SAP Help Portal – FOREACH Statement

  • SAP Help Portal – ATTR Function

  • SAP Help Portal – DATEDIFF Function

  • SAP Help Portal – PERIODSTART / PERIODEND Functions

entry.title: Re: How to add Custom Fields In BP transaction In custome...
entry.content:
Hello @Vishal__2546 

In SAP S/4HANA (including Private Cloud Edition), you cannot directly enhance the BP transaction (tcode BP) using traditional append structures. Enhancements are performed through the Custom Fields and Logic (CFL) framework.

Supported Approach

Add Custom Fields via CFL

    • Go to the Fiori app “Custom Fields and Logic” (App ID: F1481).
    • Create your custom fields (e.g. Manager Name, Contact Details).
    • Assign the fields to the Business Context: Business Partner – Customer (Master Data).
    • Publish the fields → this will add them automatically to:
      • The BP UI (Fiori and tcode BP) as a new section/tab,
      • The relevant CDS views, APIs, and iDoc structures (if enabled).

Add to UI (Custom Tab)

    • After publishing, you can enable these fields in the UI Adaptation mode of the Business Partner app.
    • You can either place them in an existing tab (e.g. General Data, Customer: Company Code) or create a new custom tab/section for clarity.

Flow to Standard Tables

  • Enable the field for the relevant Business Scenarios (Sales, Service, etc.) when creating the field in CFL.
  • Use the BAdIs in CFL (e.g. Enhance Business Partner Master Data) to populate mapping into standard structures.
    • By default, custom fields are stored in extension include tables (e.g. CI_EEW_BUT000 for BP general data).
    • If you need them to “flow” into specific downstream processes (sales orders, customer master tables, etc.), you must:

Alternative: Custom Tab in BP (Classic)

    • In S/4HANA on-premise or private edition, you can still use the BUPT transaction (Business Partner Set Types & Screens) to create a Custom Tab with a Set Type and assign it to the BP role.
    • This requires ABAP development (APPENDS, set type assignment, field grouping).
    • In Public Cloud, this is not available; you must use CFL.

Recommendation

  • For S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition → You can use both:
    • CFL (preferred) for flexibility, Fiori enablement, and API exposure.
    • Classic BDT (Business Data Toolset) if you specifically want a custom tab in tcode BP.
  • For S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition → Only CFL is supported.

Let me know if its helpful

With kind regards

Chuma

SAP DOCUMENT References:

  • SAP Help – Custom Fields and Logic
  • SAP Help – Extensibility for Business Partner
  • Adding Field in standard Fiori apps of S/4HANA with Custom Fields and Logic

entry.title: Re: Profit Center Assignment in Customer/Supplier in SAP...
entry.content:
Hello @prince_ebi 

Thank you for bringing up this question. You are correct that in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Edition, the Post General Journal Entries app does not allow postings directly to Customer or Supplier reconciliation accounts. This separation between subledger and G/L postings is intentional by design.

As Jeremy pointed out, there is a legitimate alternative:

  • You can use the Create Supplier Invoice or Create Customer Invoice apps and select the Complex Posting option.
  • This feature enables you to add extra G/L, customer, or supplier lines within a single accounting document, allowing you to credit a supplier and debit a customer in one entry (refer to your screenshots).

However, it is important to note:

  • This approach works well if the process is linked to invoice-related postings.
  • For straightforward reclassification or clearance between customer and supplier balances, the recommended methods are
    • Using the Clear Incoming Payments / Clear Outgoing Payments apps, or
    • Posting via profit center–enabled clearing G/L accounts, then assigning profit centers directly.

This way you cover both needs:

  1. Operational flexibility (using Complex Posting when an invoice context exists).
  2. Reporting requirements (ensuring Profit Center attribution in clearing/reclassification scenarios).

With kind regards

Chuma

GenAI assist generated content

SAP Documentations References

  • SAP Help Portal – Post General Journal Entries (App F0718)
  • SAP Help Portal – Create Supplier Invoice (App F0859A)
  • SAP Help –Profit Center Derivation for Objects

entry.title: Future-Proofing Your Inventory and Warehouse Management: The SAP S/4HANA Transition Explained
entry.content:
As digital transformation accelerates, many organizations relying on SAP for their supply chain operations are facing a pivotal moment: the transition from SAP Warehouse Management (WM) to Extended Warehouse Management (EWM) and Stock Room Management (SRM) in S/4HANA. Understanding what this means for Inventory Management (IM), compliance, and long-term business agility is essential for making the right strategic decisions. 

The End of WM and SAP’s New Direction 

SAP has officially confirmed the sunset of classic Warehouse Management (WM) in S/4HANA by December 31, 2025. This date marks the end of WM compatibility licensing, regular support, and further development for WM in S/4HANA environments. After this deadline, SAP will no longer provide new features or develop WM in S/4HANA, encouraging organizations to transition to modern solutions: 

- EWM has become SAP’s strategic solution for advanced warehouse management in S/4HANA, delivering deep process control, automation, real-time inventory visibility, and seamless supply chain integration. 

- Stock Room Management (SRM) is available for warehouses with simpler, manual processes, offering basic WM-like functions without further innovation planned. 

What About ECC and WM? 

For organizations still running SAP ECC (ERP Central Component), the support landscape is a bit different: 

- Mainstream maintenance for WM on ECC continues until December 31, 2027. SAP will provide full support, including bug fixes and security patches through this date. 

- After 2027, extended maintenance is available until December 31, 2030, primarily focused on critical issue support without any new functionalities. 

- This gives ECC customers a longer runway to plan their migration, but no new WM innovations will be released after 2027. 

In contrast, S/4HANA customers will need to address the WM transition by the end of 2025 due to licensing and support changes. 

Inventory Management (IM): The Backbone of Your Warehouse Strategy 

Across all solutions—WM, SRM, or EWM—Inventory Management (IM) remains the central system for managing stock quantities, values, and transaction postings at the storage location level. 

- In classic WM and Stock Room Management, IM handles stock postings, and warehouse modules add bin-level tracking and operational control. 

- In EWM, IM and EWM work closely: IM manages the legal and financial inventory view, while EWM provides bin-level, process-heavy warehouse control. 

- This layered integration ensures accuracy, compliance, and advanced warehouse execution tailored to the complexity of your business. 

Why This Matters for Your Business 

Missing the WM 2025 deadline for S/4HANA or delaying ECC migration could expose your company to unsupported software risks, compliance challenges, and operational inefficiencies. Proactive planning enables you to: 

- Continue receiving SAP support and innovations. 

- Unlock advanced warehouse automation, real-time analytics, and integrated supply chain execution with EWM. 

- Simplify operations with Stock Room Management if warehouse complexity is low. 

- Maintain precise inventory control and compliance through IM integration. 

EWM vs. Stock Room Management: Which Path is Right for You? 

Solution 

Best For 

Features 

Limitations 

Stock Room Management 

Small, manual warehouses 

Basic bin-level inventory 

No future development 

EWM 

Complex, automated warehouses 

Advanced automation, analytics 

Requires implementation 

 

No matter the choice, IM continues as the backbone of inventory tracking and compliance within your SAP system. 

Time to Future-Proof Your Warehouse 

The clock is ticking. Are you ready for SAP’s new warehouse landscape? 

Whether you aim for the simplicity of Stock Room Management or the full power of EWM, success depends on understanding your specific warehouse needs, aligning with your long-term business objectives, and executing a thoughtful migration strategy. 

Ready to Secure Your Competitive Advantage? 

Let’s talk!  

Book a consultation to assess your current SAP inventory and warehouse setup and build a tailored roadmap to future-proof your operations beyond WM’s end of life. 

Book. a call or send a message to start your journey toward streamlined, resilient warehouse management. Your supply chain deserves the best—let’s make it happen. 

#SAP #S4HANA #ECC #Warehousing #EWM #StockRoomManagement #InventoryManagement #DigitalTransformation #Consulting #FutureProof #2BM #2BMSoftware #SOApeople

entry.title: Re: Resource not found for segment 'A_BusinessPartnerAddr...
entry.content:
Hello @MansoorCPI 

The error you are encountering is attributable to the request path in your CPI iFlow referencing the entity type (A_BusinessPartnerAddressType) rather than the entity set (A_BusinessPartnerAddress). In SAP S/4HANA Cloud, it is imperative that OData operations consistently utilise the entity set.

How to Correct the error

Update the resource path in CPI (OData V2 Receiver Adapter):

/A_BusinessPartnerAddress(BusinessPartner='<BP>',AddressID='<ADDR_ID>')

Do not use /A_BusinessPartnerAddressType.

https://api.sap.com/api/API_BUSINESS_PARTNER/resource/Email_Address

(check A_BusinessPartnerAddress entity set)

Set the required HTTP headers:

Working with OData Services 

  • Content-Type: application/json
  • If-Match: * (or provide the actual ETag)
  • x-csrf-token: <token> (if session handling is not managed)

 Send only updatable fields in the PATCH body. For example:

{

  "CityName": "Austin",

  "PostalCode": "73301",

  "Country": "US"

}

Avoid selecting all fields in the adapter, since read-only properties will cause errors.

Check related entities:

    • Phone/email/fax details are separate entities: A_BusinessPartnerAddressPhone, A_BusinessPartnerAddressEmail, etc.
    • Address usages are handled with A_BPAddressUsage.
      These cannot be updated through A_BusinessPartnerAddress.

SAP API Hub – API_BUSINESS_PARTNER, Address and Contact Entities. 

Example (PATCH request)

PATCH /sap/opu/odata/sap/API_BUSINESS_PARTNER/

A_BusinessPartnerAddress(BusinessPartner='10000001',AddressID='0000000001')

PATCH /sap/opu/odata/sap/API_BUSINESS_PARTNER/

A_BusinessPartnerAddress(BusinessPartner='10000001',AddressID='0000000001')

Body:

{ "CityName": "Austin", "Country": "US" }

To rectify the error, update the path to the correct entity set (A_BusinessPartnerAddress), include the necessary key fields, and modify only the editable fields. This approach will ensure that the PATCH request operates correctly.

Let me know if it helps

With kind regards

Chuma 

 

GenAI assistance contents

SAP References:

  • SAP API Hub – Business Partner API

  • SAP Help – OData PATCH/MERGE operations

  • SAP Help – Working with OData Services in S/4HANA Cloud

entry.title: What is the best course of action for customers on IM and those in WM?
entry.content:
For customers currently using Inventory Management (IM) and those still operating with Warehouse Management (WM), the best course of action depends on their specific warehouse complexity and business needs, aligned with the SAP roadmap and support deadlines:  

For Customers on Inventory Management (IM) 

Continue using IM as the fundamental system for stock quantity and value management at the storage location level. 

- Evaluate the warehouse management needs: 

  - If your warehouse processes are basic and manual, complement IM with Stock Room Management in S/4HANA, which provides basic bin-level inventory without advanced warehouse features. 

  - For companies planning growth, automation, or increased complexity, prepare a transition to Extended Warehouse Management (EWM), which integrates tightly with IM and offers advanced control, automation, and real-time visibility. 

- IM remains your core inventory backbone regardless of the choice, ensuring compliance and financial integration. 

For Customers on Warehouse Management (WM) 

Plan and initiate migration before December 31, 2025, when WM license and support end in S/4HANA. 

- Assess warehouse complexity: 

  - If your warehouse is simple and manual, moving to Stock Room Management is the easier, quick-transition option. It requires minimal change and maintains basic WM functionality but has no future innovations planned. 

  - If your warehouse requires advanced functionality like automation, resource management, wave management, or integration with other SAP modules (e.g., PP, QM, TM), a migration to EWM (embedded or decentralized) is recommended for a future-proof solution. 

- Migration strategies can be: 

  - Gradual approach: migrate to S/4HANA first and then transition to EWM in phases. 

  - Big bang migration: a comprehensive move to EWM aligned with S/4HANA go-live. 

  - Decentralized EWM: migrate warehouse management independently of the ERP system for flexibility. 

- Early migration allows time for process optimization, change management, and leveraging EWM’s advanced features to gain competitive advantage. 

Summary Recommendations 

Customer Type 

Recommended Action 

Benefits 

Considerations 

IM-only users 

Use IM with Stock Room Management for basics; plan EWM adoption for complex needs 

Smooth transition; basic to advanced features 

Stock Room Management not innovative; EWM requires investment 

WM users in S/4HANA 

Migrate to Stock Room Management (simple) or EWM (advanced) before 12/31/2025 

Compliance, future-proofing, feature access 

Migration requires planning & resources 

WM users on ECC 

Continue WM until 12/31/2027; use extended maintenance until 2030; plan S/4HANA & EWM migration 

Longer runway; phased migration possible 

Extended maintenance limited; eventual migration necessary 

In essence, the best course of action is to start your migration planning now—whether transitioning from WM to EWM/Stock Room Management or expanding IM integration—to ensure uninterrupted support, leverage advanced capabilities, and future-proof your warehouse and inventory management in line with SAP’s evolving platform. 

Ready to Secure Your Competitive Advantage? 

Let’s talk!  

Book a consultation to assess your current SAP inventory and warehouse setup and build a tailored roadmap to future-proof your operations beyond WM’s end of life. 

Click Book a Call or send a message to start your journey toward streamlined, resilient warehouse management. Your supply chain deserves the best—let’s make it happen.

entry.title: Re: Where can I check the real-time cost of CAL?
entry.content:
Hello jewooklee ,

Almost all appliance templates available in our library offer a 30-day free trial period during which you do not need SAP Cloud Appliance Library subscription. To continue using this template beyond the free trial period, you need to purchase a SAP Cloud Appliance Library subscription and bring valid licenses for the products contained in the used by you appliance template. For more information, see this blog post .

Regardless of whether your appliance is in a trial period or beyond , you always have to pay the infrastructure costs for it directly on the cloud provider.

We have an embedded cost forecast in SAP Cloud Appliance Library. You will find a “Calculate Costs” function in the details of each Appliance Template. This function is also accessible with exploring and not logging into SAP Cloud Appliance Library.

Note that the cost calculation is based on the public hyperscaler price lists and we provide an estimated snapshot of the allocated costs. If you want to monitor your expenses strictly, then use directly the tools/console offered by the cloud provider.

Our FAQs https://pages.community.sap.com/topics/cloud-appliance-library/appliance-templates-faq/faq-subscription-costs and https://pages.community.sap.com/topics/cloud-appliance-library/appliance-templates-faq/faq-trial-templates could also be useful.

Best regards,

Tsvetinka

entry.title: Re: CDS for block function in engagement projecct
entry.content:
Hello @Shahana 

The CDS view I_EntProjElmntBlockFunc_2, mentioned in some replies, is specific to Enterprise Projects, Project System, and does not include Engagement Projects in Professional Services. That's why the block information isn't available there.

For engagement projects, the block function is accessible via dedicated CDS views.

  • C_EngagementProjectTP has released the API view, which includes the project-level block indicator, ProjectIsBlocked.
  • The C_EngmtProjWorkPkgTP includes the block indicator at the work package level, namely WorkPackageIsBlocked.

If you need a consolidated report on project, work package, and block statuses, you can create a Custom CDS View in the Custom CDS Views app by combining these released views.

Please use C_EngagementProjectTP and C_EngmtProjWorkPkgTP for Engagement Projects instead of I_EntProjElmntBlockFunc_2, which is only applicable to Enterprise Projects.

SAP Documentation References,

  • SAP Help – Engagement Project CDS Views
  • SAP API Hub – Engagement Project API

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: How to post noted items in S4H Cloud
entry.content:
Hello @nurulaffzan 

In SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Public Edition, manually posting items with posting keys is not possible; instead, noted items are automatically generated via the Bank Guarantee Management process Scope Item 2NZ  Display Treasury Alerts - Posting

This is how it works

Activate Scope Item 2NZ – Bank Guarantee Management in your system via Central Business Configuration (CBC).

Use the Manage Bank Guarantees app to create a new guarantee.

    • You can issue or receive guarantees.
    • You maintain details such as guarantee type, amount, validity period, and bank.

When the guarantee is saved, the system automatically generates a noted item in the background.

    • This noted item is statistical (it does not update balances).
    • It can be monitored in apps such as Display Line Items in General Ledger or directly in Manage Bank Guarantees.

The specified item remains until the guarantee either expires or is settled, ensuring its continued visibility in receivables and payables reports.

You will be able to optimise below processes.

  • Full tracking of guarantees (expiry, due dates, amount).
  • Automatic integration with Accounts Receivable and Accounts Payable.
  • Elimination of manual posting of noted items.

Let me know if it helps

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: CAP with Local App Previews – Tips for Smooth Development
entry.content:
UI5 has recently introduced Virtual Endpoints, eliminating the need for sandbox files and reducing maintenance effort in local previews. For details, please read the blog post below:

https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/streamlining-local-app-previews-virtual-endpoints-for-seamless-development/ba-p/14155498

I have tried virtual endpoints with CAP Node.js, and would like to share a few things I noticed.

TypeScript as a prerequisite

By default, you will not see the "Use virtual endpoints for local preview" option. This option becomes available once you enable TypeScript.

Select the #app-preview endpoint for testing the app inside Fiori Launchpad

When you start the server with `cds watch`, you will see several options for opening the app. The #app-preview option is optimal choice for testing the app inside the Fiori Launchpad (sandbox).

Reinstall dependencies after build

After building the MTA, you will not see the virtual endpoints anymore. This is due to the `npm ci` command executed during the build (I haven't dug deeper into the cause). To enable the virtual endpoints again, simply run `npm install`.

That's it. I hope this post is useful.

entry.title: Re: How to Synchronize Production Order Dates Back to Net...
entry.content:
There is no standard functionality to automatically change a PS schedule based on production orders. 

I never advised clients to automatically update the PS project schedule because something slipped in production.  In the STO process the PS schedule reflects the agreement with the customer such as when you will ship the final assembly.

When PS sends to reservation date to MRP it should stand as a requirement.  If the PP order cannot meet the demand date then someone needs to negotiate a new date, MRP acts as a referee and you can see the exception mismatches.  If you automatically change the PS schedule then everything looks in agreement and you lose visibility of the date exceptions.

entry.title: Re: initial project stock upload 561Q is not reflected in cji3 report or plan/actual report
entry.content:
Conversions can be tricky.

Please check the following:

1.  Are your project using Valuated or Non-Valuated Project Stock?

2.  Are your WBS elements statistical?

3.  For Valuated Project stock it looks like you have done everything correct where the 561Q has but the material into inventory on a quantity and value basis.  You won't see actual costs on the project until the material GI to the project.

4.  There is a way to record a valuated project stock GR against a balance sheet G/L account via a Statistical Cost Element.  

From a business perspective what are you missing from the 561Q posting?

entry.title: SAP Business AI – Driving the Next Wave of Enterprise Innovation
entry.content:
Why It Matters

AI is no longer a distant concept—it’s transforming how businesses operate today. Generative AI alone is projected to add up to $4.4 trillion in global productivity within the next five years. For SAP customers, who generate 87% of the world’s commerce, the impact of embedding AI directly into core business processes is both immediate and profound.

Key Highlights:

Joule – The AI Copilot

  • Acts as SAP’s unified front end, enabling users to work in natural language.

  • Delivers context-aware insights, transaction execution, and navigation across SAP apps.

  • Boosts efficiency by up to 80% for employees.

  • Coordinates specialized AI agents for complex tasks (e.g., dispute resolution, sustainability planning).

  • Integrates with Microsoft Copilot for Office 365 for seamless cross-platform experiences.

Embedded AI – Innovation at Scale

  • AI features are built directly into SAP’s cloud solutions (ERP, Supply Chain, HCM, CRM, Procurement, etc.).

  • Use cases already improving business outcomes:

    • Henkel → Faster, data-driven decisions with AI in SAP Analytics Cloud.

    • FC Bayern Munich → Accelerated recruiting with generative AI in SAP SuccessFactors.

    • Gibson → Boosted email revenue by 50% through AI-powered customer engagement.

  • Over 100+ new AI features released in 2024, with continuous quarterly rollouts.

AI Foundation – Building Custom Solutions

  • Part of SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP).

  • Provides developers with reusable AI services, lifecycle management, and access to leading LLMs (OpenAI, Google, AWS, Meta, etc.).

  • Offers deep integration with SAP HANA Cloud Vector Engine and SAP Knowledge Graph for contextualized business data.

  • Enables low-data AI innovation, such as invoice due date predictions or sales order auto-filling .

Responsible AI at SAP

  • Commitment to ethics, privacy, and security:

    • No partner or third-party models are trained on customer data.

    • AI ethics embedded in governance via SAP’s AI Ethics Steering Committee.

    • Guardrails against misuse, bias, and security risks.

  • Alignment with UNESCO AI ethics standards and EU AI Act compliance .

SAP’s vision is AI-first and suite-first:

  • AI copilots like Joule will become hyper-personalized.

  • More AI-driven automation across finance, HR, supply chain, and sustainability.

The future is already here. With SAP Business AI, organizations can run better, innovate faster, and empower people to focus on what truly matters.

entry.title: AI‑Powered Self‑Service Portal with SAP Build Apps and SAP Service Cloud V2
entry.content:
Abstract

In this demo, we showcase an intelligent self‑service portal built with SAP Build Apps, seamlessly integrated with SAP Service Cloud V2 and SAP AI Core. End users submit a service request by uploading an image . The image is analyzed in AI Core to detect key objects or issues; the findings are then merged into the case description so agents start with rich context. We also run sentiment analysis on the user’s text, helping auto‑prioritize and categorize the case. The result is an end‑to‑end, low‑code + AI workflow that reduces manual effort, improves accuracy, and accelerates resolution time.

Use Case: Broken Home Appliance Service Request

Scenario:
A customer’s washing machine stops working and makes unusual noise. Instead of calling customer support, they log into the self-service portal built on SAP Build Apps.

What you’ll build

A responsive self‑service portal where customers can:

  • Log in, fill a lightweight form, and upload a photo (e.g., broken product/utility issue).
  • See real‑time AI insights (objects detected; suspected issue) before submitting.
  • Submit a Service Request (Case) to Service Cloud V2, with AI context appended to the description and sentiment tag auto‑set.

Agents in Service Cloud V2 will see a richer ticket with:

  • Customer text + image URL/attachment.
  • AI object/issue summary and confidence scores.
  • Sentiment label (Positive/Neutral/Negative) for quick triage.

Solution Overview

The solution leverages three modern SAP technologies:

  • SAP Build Apps: Low-code environment for building web/mobile self-service portals.
  • SAP BTP Destination: Secure connection layer to backend SAP services.
  • SAP Service Cloud V2: Manages and tracks customer service cases.
  • SAP AI Core: Automates image analysis and sentiment analysis to enhance ticket information

The workflow (as visualized below) demonstrates how these layers interact:

  • End-to-End Ticket Automation: Instantly raise service requests by uploading an image.
  • AI-Powered Image Analysis: Automatic detection of objects or issues in uploaded images via SAP AI Core.
  • Auto-Enriched Ticket Descriptions: AI writes relevant context and details.
  • Sentiment Analysis: Analyzes customer descriptions for emotion and urgency for better case triaging.

Reference architecture

 

Prerequisites

Before starting, ensure you have the following in place:

SAP BTP Account with access to:

  • SAP Build Apps service
  • SAP AI Core service
  • SAP Service Cloud V2 tenant

Service Keys and Destinations:

  • Properly configured SAP BTP Destination for Service Cloud V2 and SAP AI Core

AI Models Deployed:

  • Object Detection model ( in SAP AI Core)
  • Sentiment Analysis model
  • Basic understanding of SAP BTP, Destinations, and Service Cloud concepts

Step‑by‑step build guide

1.Prepare Your AI Services in SAP AI Core

  • Deploy or onboard your image recognition and sentiment analysis models to SAP AI Core.
  • Expose these models through RESTful endpoints.

2. Configure Destinations in SAP BTP Cockpit

Create destinations for:

  • SAP Service Cloud V2 API
  • SAP AI Core inference endpoints
  • Set appropriate authentication methods (OAuth2, Basic, etc.).

3.Build the Self-Service Portal with SAP Build Apps

  • Use SAP Build Apps’ drag-and-drop interface to design a user-friendly portal.
  • Add functionality for:
    • User authentication
    • Image upload
    • Input fields for additional ticket information
  • Configure data resources to connect to SAP Service Cloud V2 and SAP AI Core via the BTP destinations.

Build the portal in SAP Build Apps

Step 1: Create an SAP Build Apps portal tailored to your requirements.

Step 2: Implement logic to process the uploaded image using SAP AI Core. Extract the description from the image and perform sentiment analysis on the extracted text. Based on the description and sentiment, automatically update the subject line and categorize the case accordingly.

Step 3: Invoke the Service Cloud V2 API to create a case along with the attachment.

Video

 

Summary

This approach shows how you can build a pure destination‑driven integration between Build Apps, AI Core, and Service Cloud V2. By leveraging SAP BTP Destinations, you eliminate the need for custom middleware, keep the architecture lightweight, and still enable AI‑powered case creation with images, sentiment, and prioritization.

entry.title: Re: Material ledger not active in plant … error message w...
entry.content:
Hi @arionnurit1 

The error means you need to activate the Material Ledger for your plant specific valuation area first.

This is how I suggest you solve the issue:

First, go to transaction code OMX1 and activate the Material Ledger for your plant or valuation area. Set the price determination, this is usually 2 for transaction based.

Then assign the Material Ledger type to your plant using OMX3.

Ensure that your Quantity or Value updating is enabled for your material type and plant in OMS2. And save your changes.

Finally, return to CKMSTART then enter your plant, untick Background Processing for a test run and then execute. Once you confirmed it then run the process productively.

This process will activate and set your plant productive for Material Ledger, allowing CKMSTART to execute successfully

I hope this provides the necessary information. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: How is DEPENDENTLOCATIONDEMANDMEAN calculated in IO?
entry.content:
Hi,

I am trying to understand how the key figure DEPENDENTLOCATIONDEMANDMEAN is calculated but unfortunately there are no sap notes giving a hint. I looked at the calculations mentioned in SAP Note 2718582. It indicates calculations for demand that the receiving location puts on the supplying location. The standard key figure DEPENDENTLOCATIONDEMANDMEAN has the same definition and planning level but does not match the calculations in the SAP note as shown in the attachment. Has someone cracked how this key figure DEPENDENTLOCATIONDEMANDMEAN is calculated? The key figure is significant as its standard deviation is counted in the Propagated Demand Standard Deviation of the upstream node and hence is part of Recommended safety stock calculations. 

Thanks,

Zeeshan

FLOAT @LastPct
FLOAT @TotalPctShortfall = 0
FLOAT @TotalCapPctShortfall = 0
FLOAT @CapPct
FLOAT @Spending
FLOAT @UncapBalance = 0
FLOAT @CapAmount
FLOAT @REMAININGBUDGET
VARIABLEMEMBER #Depreciable_Amt OF [d/Account]
VARIABLEMEMBER #Capitilized_Amt OF [d/Account]
VARIABLEMEMBER #uncap OF [d/Account]
MODEL [Investment Plan Model]
MEMBERSET [d/DIM_STRATEGICKPI].[p/Type] = "CAPEX"
MEMBERSET [d/DIM_PROJECT] = "#"
ENDMODEL
 
FOREACH [d/DIM_WBS_PROJECT]
 
@StartYear = ATTRIBUTE([d/DIM_WBS_PROJECT].[p/BUDGETEDYEAR])
@ENERGIZEDYEAR = ATTRIBUTE([d/DIM_WBS_PROJECT].[p/ENERGIZEDYEAR])
@USEFULLIFE = ATTRIBUTE([d/DIM_WBS_PROJECT].[p/USEFULLIFE])
@ProjectLife = @ENERGIZEDYEAR - @StartYear + 1
 
@TotalBudget = RESULTLOOKUP(
[d/Measures] = "Amount",
[d/Account] = "CAPEX_003",
[d/Date] = [d/DIM_WBS_PROJECT].[p/BUDGETEDYEAR],
[d/Version] = "public.Actual"
   )
 
// --- Sum extra % beyond project life ---
@TotalPctShortfall = 0
@KPIIndex = 0
 
FOREACH [Investment Plan Model].[d/DIM_STRATEGICKPI].[p/SORT]
IF [Investment Plan Model].[d/DIM_PROJECTTYPE] = [d/DIM_WBS_PROJECT].[p/PROJECTTYPE] THEN
 
@PCT = LINK(
[Investment Plan Model],
[d/DIM_CAPEX_ACCOUNT] = "CAPEX_SPENDPERCENT",
[d/Date] = "2070",
[d/Measures] = "Value",
[d/Version] = "public.Assumptions",
[d/DIM_AUDIT] = "INPUT_FP",
[d/DIM_SCENARIO] = "#",
[d/DIM_BUSINESSLINE] = "NOBUSINESSLINE",
[d/DIM_COSTCENTER] = "#",
[d/DIM_PROJECTTYPE] = [d/DIM_WBS_PROJECT].[p/PROJECTTYPE]
   )
@CapPct = LINK([Investment Plan Model], [d/DIM_CAPEX_ACCOUNT] = "CAPEX_CAPPERCENT", [d/Date] = "2070", [d/Measures] = "Value", [d/Version] = "public.Assumptions", [d/DIM_AUDIT] = "INPUT_FP", [d/DIM_SCENARIO] = "#", [d/DIM_BUSINESSLINE] = "NOBUSINESSLINE", [d/DIM_COSTCENTER] = "#", [d/DIM_PROJECTTYPE] = [d/DIM_WBS_PROJECT].[p/PROJECTTYPE]
  )
 
// If project life < matrix: accumulate leftover % AFTER the project life
IF @KPIIndex >= @ProjectLife AND @KPIIndex < @MatrixYears THEN
@TotalPctShortfall = @TotalPctShortfall + @PCT
@TotalCapPctShortfall = @TotalCapPctShortfall + @CapPct
ENDIF
 
// Capture last matrix pct (last KPI member)
IF @KPIIndex = @MatrixYears - 1 THEN
@LastPct = @PCT
ENDIF
 
@KPIIndex = @KPIIndex + 1
ENDIF
ENDFOR
 
// --- Loop through years ---
FOREACH [d/Date]
 
@DateYear = YEAR([d/Date])
@OffsetYear = @DateYear - @StartYear
// stop after project life
IF @OffsetYear >= @ProjectLife THEN
BREAK
ENDIF
IF @OffsetYear >= 0 AND @OffsetYear < @ProjectLife THEN
 
// Find matching KPI member index to offset year
@KPIIndex = 0
@PCT = 0
@CapPct = 0
FOREACH [Investment Plan Model].[d/DIM_PROJECTTYPE]
IF [Investment Plan Model].[d/DIM_PROJECTTYPE] = [d/DIM_WBS_PROJECT].[p/PROJECTTYPE] THEN
FOREACH [Investment Plan Model].[d/DIM_STRATEGICKPI].[p/SORT]
IF @KPIIndex = @OffsetYear AND @OffsetYear < @MatrixYears - 1 THEN
@PCT = LINK([Investment Plan Model], [d/DIM_PROJECTTYPE]=[d/DIM_WBS_PROJECT].[p/PROJECTTYPE],[d/DIM_CAPEX_ACCOUNT] = "CAPEX_SPENDPERCENT", [d/Date] = "2070", [d/Measures] = "Value", [d/Version] = "public.Assumptions", [d/DIM_AUDIT] = "INPUT_FP", [d/DIM_SCENARIO] = "#", [d/DIM_BUSINESSLINE] = "NOBUSINESSLINE", [d/DIM_COSTCENTER] = "#")
@CapPct = LINK([Investment Plan Model], [d/DIM_PROJECTTYPE]=[d/DIM_WBS_PROJECT].[p/PROJECTTYPE],
 [d/DIM_CAPEX_ACCOUNT] = "CAPEX_CAPPERCENT", [d/Date] = "2070", [d/Measures] = "Value", [d/Version] = "public.Assumptions", [d/DIM_AUDIT] = "INPUT_FP", [d/DIM_SCENARIO] = "#", [d/DIM_BUSINESSLINE] = "NOBUSINESSLINE", [d/DIM_COSTCENTER] = "#")
// If last year and project life < matrix, add surplus %
IF @OffsetYear = @ProjectLife - 1 AND @ProjectLife < @MatrixYears THEN
@PCT = @PCT + @TotalPctShortfall
@CapPct = @CapPct + @TotalCapPctShortfall
ENDIF
ENDIF
 
// Case 2: Year is beyond matrix but project life continues → redistribute leftover
IF @OffsetYear >= @MatrixYears - 1 AND @OffsetYear < @ProjectLife THEN
@RemainingYears = @ProjectLife - (@MatrixYears - 1)
IF @RemainingYears > 0 THEN
@PCT = @LastPct / @RemainingYears
ELSE
@PCT = 0
ENDIF
ENDIF
 
@Spending = @TotalBudget * (@Pct / 100)
 
// Add spending to uncapitalized balance
@UncapBalance = @Spending + @UncapBalance
DATA([d/Measures] = "Amount", [d/Account] = "CAPEX_001") = @Spending
DATA([d/Account] = #uncap) = RESULTLOOKUP([d/Account] = "CAPEX_001") + RESULTLOOKUP([d/Account] = #uncap, [d/Date] = PREVIOUS(1))
 
// CWIP calculation
DATA([d/Account] = "CAPEX_012") = RESULTLOOKUP([d/Account] = "CAPEX_012", [d/Date] = PREVIOUS(1)) + RESULTLOOKUP([d/Account] = "CAPEX_001")
// Capitalize on total uncapitalized balance
@CapAmount = RESULTLOOKUP([d/Account] = #uncap) * (@CapPct / 100)
 
// If it's the energized year → force capitalize all remaining
IF @DateYear = @ENERGIZEDYEAR THEN
@CapAmount = RESULTLOOKUP([d/Account] = #uncap)
@UncapBalance = 0
ELSE
DATA([d/Account] = #uncap) = RESULTLOOKUP([d/Account] = #uncap) - @CapAmount
ENDIF
 
// Store capitalization amount
DATA([d/Measures] = "Amount", [d/Account] = "CAPEX_002") = @CapAmount
 
@KPIIndex = @KPIIndex + 1
ENDFOR 
ENDIF
ENDFOR
ENDIF
 
//         // --- Depreciation ---
//         IF RESULTLOOKUP([d/Account] = "CAPEX_002") != Null THEN
//             @Move = 0
//             FOR @count = 1 TO @USEFULLIFE
//                 DATA.APPEND([d/Account] = #Depreciable_Amt, [d/Date] = NEXT(@Move)) = RESULTLOOKUP([d/Account] = "CAPEX_002")
//                 @Move = @Move + 1
//             ENDFOR
//         ENDIF
 
//         DATA([d/Account] = "CAPEX_004", [d/Date] = NEXT(1)) = RESULTLOOKUP([d/Account] = #Depreciable_Amt) / @USEFULLIFE
//         DATA([d/Account] = "CAPEX_007") = RESULTLOOKUP([d/Account] = "CAPEX_002")
 
//         IF RESULTLOOKUP([d/Account] = "CAPEX_004") != Null THEN
//             DATA([d/Account] = "CAPEX_005") = RESULTLOOKUP([d/Account] = "CAPEX_005", [d/Date] = PREVIOUS(1)) + RESULTLOOKUP([d/Account] = "CAPEX_004")
//             DATA([d/Account] = "CAPEX_007") = RESULTLOOKUP([d/Account] = "CAPEX_007", [d/Date] = PREVIOUS(1)) + RESULTLOOKUP([d/Account] = "CAPEX_002")
//             DATA([d/Account] = "CAPEX_006") = RESULTLOOKUP([d/Account] = "CAPEX_007", [d/Date] = PREVIOUS(1)) - RESULTLOOKUP([d/Account] = "CAPEX_005")
//         ENDIF
 
//         IF RESULTLOOKUP([d/Account] = "CAPEX_004") != Null OR RESULTLOOKUP([d/Account] = "CAPEX_002") != Null THEN
//             DATA([d/Account] = "CAPEX_015") = RESULTLOOKUP([d/Account] = "CAPEX_016", [d/Date] = PREVIOUS(1))
//             DATA([d/Account] = "CAPEX_016") =
//                 RESULTLOOKUP([d/Account] = "CAPEX_015") +
//                 RESULTLOOKUP([d/Account] = "CAPEX_002") -
//                 RESULTLOOKUP([d/Account] = "CAPEX_004")
//         ENDIF
ENDFOR
ENDFOR

Thanks.
